author: Jeffy Mai
title: Chicago's 10 Toughest Tables, 2017 Edition
text:
Chicago's 10 Toughest Tables, 2017 Edition All Mar 23, 2017, 12:30pm CDT There's a strong chance you've waited outside Au Cheval before Facebook 
In a world-class culinary city where new restaurants open on a daily basis, buzz comes and goes in a fleeting instant. There are many hotspots that require waits but the following tables are hands down the most difficult to land. If you're looking to dine at one of these places, read on to get the lowdown on how to avoid waiting countless hours or worse yet, getting turned away. 
Few restaurants can keep the initial hype train rolling except for the very best. Those who seek fine dining will have to do their due diligence to get into Chicago's top Michelin-starred spots such as Alinea , Grace , and Oriole . But it's not just the high-end tables that need advance planning. Other popular eateries—like Au Cheval and Big Star —don't accept reservations but have optimal times to go. Even if there are lines though, the best things come to those who wait ... right? Listed in alphabetical order. 1 Alinea 
Grant Achatz’s acclaimed three-Michelin-starred restaurant is among the best in the world. With that honor comes throngs of diners, from near and far, champing at the bit to experience the chef’s mind-bending brand of molecular gastronomy. To secure a table, guests need to pre-purchase upfront on Tock , the reservation system founded by Alinea co-owner Nick Kokonas. Tickets include the cost of the meal and go on sale several months in advance. For the most up-to-date info on ticket releases, follow the restaurant on social media . Matthew Gilson
